Dennis de Jong, managing director at UFXMarkets: This is the fifth successive month the reading has risen above 200,000 with job growth significantly rebounding this quarter following a poor start to the year. webTitle: FTSE 100 rises to three week high as US jobs data pushes Dow beyond 17,000

fields.standfirst: Global markets surge after positive non farm payroll numbers fuel global growth hopes
fields.body:
Leading shares surged to a three week high, helped by the Dow Jones Industrial Average hitting 17,000 for the first time following positive US jobs figures.

The FTSE 100 finished 48.84 points higher at 6865.21, its best level since 10 June on the combination of upbeat economic data and the continuing support of central bank stimulus measures. The index is now within 65 points of its all time record close. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

European markets had been on a firmer footing even before this afternoon's US jobs report, given that the European Central Bank surprised nobody by leaving policy unchanged.
Heading into the long US weekend expectations had been high that this afternoon's US jobs report was going to be a good one, and I'm sure the ECB President had his fingers crossed that the numbers would follow on from yesterday's ADP numbers, and help make his job easier in terms of weakening the euro at the expense of the US dollar. It turns out he needn't have worried, as not only did the June numbers beat expectations, but the April and May numbers were revised up as well. Against this backdrop Europe's markets have remained well supported continuing to build on this week's gains with the German Dax regaining the 10,000 level for the first time in nearly two weeks.

There were a broad range of risers, with mining group Antofagasta adding 38.5p to 820p and Fresnillo rising 29p to 933.5p.

Sports Direct International was the biggest riser in the leading index after shareholders approved the controversial bonus plan for Mike Ashley (and others, of course). Its shares ended 41p better at 769p. Liberum analysts said:

From an investment perspective, we think that resolution of this issue removes a degree of uncertainty around the business and we can now re-focus on the longer term growth story.
There are still issues that need to be resolved around the relationship with adidas, but a recent visit to the new Oxford St flagship gives a strong indication of Sports Direct's intent to improve its store format gradually. We would see the recent share price weakness as an opportunity to buy ahead of preliminary results on 17 July (we expect the company to meet market expectations of around £330m underlying EBITDA).

But a dip on the oil price helped send Royal Dutch Shell A shares 26p lower to £24.04 and BP down 2.9p to 516.9p.

Back with retail, Poundland put on 13.2p to 341.9p after well received results showed an 18% rise in first quarter sales.

Tesco was up 5.85p at 290.8p and Morrisons climbed 2.6p to 182.2p after Nomura added both to its European recommended portfolio.

But Balfour Beatty dropped 10.5p or 4.5% to 222.5p after it said it would take a £35m hit to profits following poor trading at its mechanical and electrical engineering division.

Brewer Greene King lost 30.5p to 816.5p despite a 7.4% rise in full year profits to £173.1m, as trading in the early part of the year proved disappointing. Numis said:

We are holding our consensus-in- line 2015 forecasts, which anticipate 4% pretax profit growth. Given this and having missed out in the bidding for Orchid, we expect Greene King to be looking for acquisitions.
However, like for like sales are up a disappointing 1.1% in early 2015 despite the fine weather, the World Cup and relatively easy comparisons.

Elsewhere troubled outsourcer Serco slipped 3.3p to 363p as it warned that it will need to make provisions in its first half figures for a number of loss-making contracts.

Lower down the market MoPowered fell 3p to 29p after the mobile commerce specialist - which warned on Tuesday that contract delays would hit its results - said finance director Ben Carswell was stepping down with immediate effect.

Finally Quadrise Fuels International jumped nearly 16% to 36.5p as its low-cost alternative to fuel oil in the shipping, refining and power generation markets moved closer to commercial production. After positive test results, Maersk advised the company that the "proof of concept" requirements for its MSAR marine fuel had been satisfied. Peel Hunt said:

Maersk has advised that the requirements for the important marine "proof of concept" tests have been satisfied in the Wärtsilä engine type confirming good engine and emissions performance. This is very important as it enables Maersk to proceed to the "letter of no objection" stage, which is the final pre-condition required ahead of starting commercial roll-out to a select set of vessels.

webTitle: US adds 288,000 jobs in June as unemployment rate drops to 6.1%

fields.standfirst: Figure far exceeds analysts' expectations as US economy posts fifth straight month of job growth
fields.body:
The US economy gained 288,000 jobs in June and the unemployment rate declined to 6.1%, the Labor Department reported Thursday, in advance of the Fourth of July holiday.

The Labor Department called the job gains "widespread," with growth in professional and business services, retail and food services. All three major indices opened up about one-third a percentage point on the news. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 63 points, topping 17,000 for the first time. The Nasdaq opened 15 points higher and the S&P 500 is up 15 points.

Wall Street analysts had expected to see around 215,000 jobs created in June, and an unchanged unemployment rate of 6.3%, or 9.8 million people out of work. That number declined to 9.5 million.

The number of jobs in the economy grew despite weak first quarter growth, when the economy shrank by 2.9%.

The number of long-term unemployed, those without work for 27 weeks or more, also declined by 293,000 in June, to 3.1m. In May, these workers accounted for a little more than one-third of the total number of unemployed. That number also dropped – they now account for 32.8% of the total unemployed.

The labor market participation rate, the number of people of working age who are working or seeking employment held steady at 62.8% in June. It hasn't changed for the past three months.

The department also revised April and May jobs numbers up. In April the numbers rose to 304,000 from 282,000, and in May the numbers rose from 217,000 to 224,000.

Most of the June employment gains were in professional and business services, in sectors such as consulting, computer and architectural services, where the economy added 67,000 jobs. Retail employment added 40,000 jobs, food service added 33,000 and healthcare added 21,000, followed by transportation, financial services and manufacturing.

Workers who had part-time work but wanted full-time work, sometimes referred to as "involuntary part-time workers" is down over the year, but increased by 275,000 in June, for a total of 7.5m workers overall.

At least 2m workers weren't counted as unemployed because they hadn't looked for work in the last month, possibly because of family responsibilities or school attendance. Discouraged workers, those who are available for work but don't believe there are jobs for them, was 676,000 people in June. That number is down by 351,000 from year before.

Numbers released by the Department of Labor on Thursday reflected those released Wednesday by ADP, the country's largest payroll company. The country added 281,000 jobs according to that report.

webTitle: Tullow Oil lifted by small discovery in Norwegian arctic

fields.standfirst: A day after disappointing investors with $415m write down, oil explorer reports new find
fields.body:
A day after unsettling the market with a $415m write off, Tullow Oil had better news for investors.

The oil explorer and producer announced a small oil discovery in the Norwegian arctic, prompting hopes of a new area for development. The wildcat well on the Hanssen discovery, where Tullow has a 20% interest, encountered a 20 to 25 metre oil bearing sandstone. It estimated up to 50m barrels of recoverable oil from the discovery, confirming the potential of the Wisting discovery. Tullow exploration director Angus McCoss said:

This success is an important follow-up to our Wisting Central oil discovery in September last year which opened up the Hoop area. The Hanssen discovery gives us significant insight into the potential of the Wisting cluster and further confidence that we are on track towards proving up a major new commercial oil reserve.

Tullow's shares have added 6.5p to 856p but some analysts were slightly underwhelmed. Oriel Securities said:

Largely neutral for Tullow shares, given that this discovery on its own it is likely to be immaterial to Tullow. According to the company the well was targeting gross 110m barrels of oil equivalent of prospective resources.

And Mark Henderson at Westhouse Securites said:

While a successful discovery is clearly positive for sentiment, the size of the discovery is smaller than hoped and is ultimately not particularly material in the context of Tullow's larger portfolio, adding just 1p to our risked net asset value. We maintain our add rating and 960p target price.

But SP Angel was more positive:

Tullow's announcement of a discovery in its Barent's acreage is a boon not only for Tullow, but also other operators with interests in the immediate area, such as Rex.
In comparison to the other Norwegian regions (North Sea and Norwegian Sea) the Barents Sea region is largely underexplored, and each new exploration well provides further information, not only on the basin's geology, but its prospectivity too.

And RFC Ambrian said:

The Hanssen prospect made up just $21m (1p a share) of our risked $12,579m (£8.32 a share) fair value estimate, although this was based on Tullow's pre-drill 110m barrel resource estimate of the prospect. We estimate this prospect to now be worth $50m (3p a share). We reiterate our hold recommendation.

webTitle: Asda to cut 1,360 jobs

fields.bodyText: Asda is cutting 1,360 middle managers, redeploying staff into fast-growing online shopping jobs as it attempts to take out £1bn in costs over the next five years. The Walmart-owned company said 4,100 staff were affected by the restructuring, which creates 5,670 new roles, many of them lower-paid, linked to the faster-growing home-shopping business. The supermarket said the staffing shakeup was in response to "intense structural changes" in the grocery market. The big four supermarkets are all seeking to cut costs as the era of big box retail comes to an end. On the one hand they are being forced to cut prices to compete with the fast-growing food discounters Aldi and Lidl, but they also need to invest in new sales channels such as the internet and home grocery deliveries. "As much as it is my job, and privilege, to be chief executive of this business and to do what is right for Asda as a whole, this is one of the most difficult decisions I've had to make," said its chief executive, Andy Clarke. "Whilst I genuinely believe that it is the right decision for the future of Asda, knowing that it will result in valued colleagues leaving us is not easy. Every supermarket must adapt to the intense changes in UK retailing or they will get left behind." The job cuts come months after Asda was praised by the prime minister, David Cameron, for its plans to create 12,000 new jobs over the next five years as it opened new stores. At that time, Doug McMillon, president and chief executive of Walmart, said the company was "creating more new jobs and bringing real value to more customers in the UK". The shakeup was first announced in May, when Asda said as many as 2,600 staff could go. Staff canteens are also being closed – replaced with vending machines. Asda's chief operating officer, Mark Ibbotson, who is leading the cost-reduction project, said: "We believe we are about 18 months ahead of our competitors. They're all going to have to do this." In June Morrisons also announced it was consulting staff about store management changes that could lead to as many as 2,600 job losses. Asda said the changes created "more flexible store management structures to satisfy the constantly evolving shopping habits of supermarket customers today and in the future". The company said the new structure put a greater emphasis on e-commerce and removed back-office administration tasks. Over the coming weeks managers affected by the changes will either begin training for their new jobs or take a redundancy package, it said. Before the recession the discounters were dismissed as a sideshow in UK food retail, but their rapid growth means that, taken together, Aldi and Lidl are now a bigger force than the Co-op, the country's fifth-largest supermarket chain. Some analysts believe they are a bigger strategic threat to the big supermarkets than the internet. Last month, Sainsbury's announced a joint venture with Denmark's biggest retailer, Dansk Supermarked, to relaunch the Netto discount brand in Britain, with 15 stores expected to open by the end of 2015. Shore Capital analyst Clive Black said supermarket bosses were being forced to tackle their labour costs as it is the only lever they can pull in a market where there is weak demand and intense price competition. "It is our central expectation that more jobs will go at the big supermarkets, with major initiatives expected to come with respect to head-office headcount across the industry," he said. After keeping a tight hold of the purse strings during the recession, Britons now buy less to avoid wasting food and make more frequent top-up shops at small stores as opposed to doing one large weekly shop. These changes put pressure on the economics of big box stores, which have high fixed costs. "We believe that Sainsbury's and Tesco will also announce in due course material productivity programmes involving labour shedding," adds Black in a note.

webTitle: US unemployment falls to 6.1% - and should keep on falling

fields.bodyText: It's been a long time since the jobless rate in the United States was as low as 6.1%. Indeed, you have to go back to September 2008 to find a month when unemployment was as low as it is today. That's significant because September 2008 was the month that Lehman Brothers collapsed – the event that pushed the world to the brink of financial meltdown and forced central banks into emergency action to prevent a second Great Depression. For six years, the Federal Reserve has had its foot to the floor. Interest rates have barely been above zero and trillions of dollars have been created through the quantitative easing process. So does the creation of 288,000 new non-farm payroll jobs in June and an unemployment rate of 6.1% mean that we can expect a change in the Fed's policy stance? Probably not for now, although a change in the rhetoric is perhaps not that far off. Janet Yellen, the Fed's chairman, seems relaxed enough with the way things are. She has expressed a willingness to leave policy on hold, with a gradual tapering away of the asset-purchase programme and no increase in interest rates until there is either a fall in the unemployment rate below 6% or there is an obvious acceleration in wage growth. After describing signs of growing inflationary pressure as "noise", Yellen will no doubt be comforted by the latest data from the Department for Labor in Washington showing wages were up 2% in the year to June, slightly down on the 2.1% increase recorded in May. That, though, is a bit misleading since the fall in the annual rate of earnings growth has more to do with what was happening last year than what is happening this. A bounceback in wage growth is highly likely in July. With every sign that the US economy has recovered strongly from its weather-related contraction in the first quarter of 2014, unemployment looks set to carry on falling. The Fed thinks the level of unemployment consistent with stable inflation is between 5.2% and 5.5%, not much lower than the current jobless rate. Once unemployment dips below 6%, Wall Street is going to get jumpy about inflation, whatever the Fed might say.

webTitle: Postwar baby boomers missed out on earnings, ONS says

fields.bodyText: It's 1975. Harold Wilson is the prime minister and inflation has hit a postwar peak of 26% as you are about to join the Labour market aged 21. Move forward 20 years. It's 1995, John Major is the occupant of 10 Downing Street and it is the turn of your son or daughter to get a job for the first time. Who did better? If you imagined it was the one now thinking about retirement rather than the one in middle age you would be wrong. The 1995 entrant to the labour market beats the 1975 entrant hands down. Why is this? It is not caused by inflation, because the Office for National Statistics analysis takes account of that. Instead, you have to look at the structure and the long-term performance of the economy to find the reason for the disparity. Between 1975 and 1995, the UK lost jobs in manufacturing and gained jobs in services, including financial services. Workers who joined banks or IT startups in the 1990s could earn higher wages more quickly than someone learning their trade in industry two decades earlier. Probably of more significance, though, is that someone joining the labour market in 1975 did so when the economy was stuck in its first recession since the second world war and had extremely high inflation. The cure for so-called stagflation was a three-year squeeze on real wages designed to bring inflation back down. Workers then saw two more recessions in the early 1980s and early 1990s before the 1995 cohort entered the labour market at the start of what Sir Mervyn King dubbed "the nice decade". That's nice as in non-inflationary continual expansion – a period in which the economy grew steadily year after year. The peaks were not as high as they were during the ill-fated Lawson boom of the 1980s but there were no lows in a period of uninterrupted growth that lasted more than 60 quarters between 1992 and 2007. Clearly, this was a good time to be joining the labour market. To be sure, things have looked less good for the 1995 generation since the economy went into recession in 2008. Their median hourly earnings fell by 10% from 2009 to 2013. But the downturn has had an even bigger impact on older workers, with the hourly earnings of the 1975 cohort dropping by 12% in the same period. Larry Elliott

webTitle: Ryanair restarts UK internal flights

fields.bodyText: Ryanair is restarting British domestic services, with daily flights from Glasgow and Edinburgh to London starting in the autumn. The Irish airline abandoned internal flights three years ago but believes a changing market and its own focus on business passengers makes the routes viable. Ryanair will operate three daily services each way from Stansted to the Scottish cities, setting up operations at Glasgow International instead of Prestwick for the first time. It will start selling tickets on Friday for services beginning on 26 October at a lead-in price of £19.99 – despite air passenger duty costing £13 on each ticket. Ryanair's chief marketing officer, Kenny Jacobs, said average fares would be higher but that the airline would have more seats available at its headline price than its competitors at their best advertised fares. Other airlines have struggled to make internal services turn a profit, with British Airways relinquishing several routes when it swallowed up bmi. Virgin Atlantic's domestic service, Little Red, operating between Scotland and Heathrow, flew with little more than a third of seats occupied in 2013. Jacobs said Ryanair was confident it would fill its planes because of lower overheads than other airlines. He said: "We have the most straightforward operation and the best deals with the airports. Now we've got this metronomic, seven days a week schedule, and good deals, we'll be filling the aircraft." He said he thought "others will reconsider" whether their operations are viable. The airline is also increasing the number of flights on other European business routes from Stansted, with enhanced daily schedules to 14 destinations from autumn, including four daily returns to Barcelona and three to Madrid and Lisbon. Ryanair said the flights would help it grow its comparatively low market share in the UK, which at 13% is behind EasyJet and British Airways. The first five of its 180 new 737 planes on order arrive in September. Andrew Harrison, managing director of Stansted airport, said the new schedules were "another demonstration of the strength of the relationships we have since agreeing targets for long-term growth". The airport's owners, MAG, signed a 10-year growth deal with Ryanair, its biggest customer, to boost customer numbers soon after buying Stansted from Heathrow last year. Both parties are targeting a business market they believe is expanding in what they term the "London-Cambridge corridor".

webTitle: UK service sector in for strong second half of the year after rise in new orders

fields.standfirst: Growth follows solid figures for manufacturing and construction industries and suggests economic recovery is speeding up
fields.body:
Britain's service sector is gearing up for a strong second half to the year following a surge in new orders last month, according to figures from financial data provider Markit.

Activity across the sector slowed slightly from May to June, but firms remained buoyant about their prospects through the summer and autumn, matching their enthusiasm with a strong increase in marketing costs and jobs.

Following figures showing both manufacturing and construction gaining in strength, service sector expansion indicated that GDP growth will remain at an annual rate of 3% until 2015.

Jonathan Loynes, the chief European economist at consultancy Capital Economics, said that while June marked the second month of falls in the Markit CIPS index, the available data points to a quickening in the economic recovery in the second quarter.

"Accordingly, we think that GDP could rise by a quarterly 1% or so in the second quarter," he said.

The main business activity index fell from 58.6 in May to 57.7 in June where a figure above 50 indicates growth.

The services sector accounts for 77% of the economy and has proved to be the bedrock of economic expansion following consistent growth since 2012. In 2013, it became the first sector to regain all the ground lost in the recession.

There has been a tendency for employers to hire staff on low wages to fulfil orders rather than invest in new premises and equipment, but a rise in new work and a tightening job market is likely to force firms to change course.

Markit said new orders, which have expanded each month for the last 18, grew in June at the sharpest pace in six months.

"Latest data marked the 18th month in succession that a rise in new work has been signalled, with panellists reporting that trading conditions remained positive and market confidence high in June. Marketing activities and better weather were also noted as factors driving new business higher," the report said.

Employment soared, with over 27% of the survey panel recording an increase in staff numbers since May.

Chris Williamson, chief economist at financial data provider Markit, said: "Yet another strong service sector PMI number indicates the UK economy continued to boom at the end of the second quarter. Alongside similar surveys showing an ongoing surge in construction and the largest quarterly rise in manufacturing output for 20 years, the services PMI confirms that the UK economy is firing on all cylinders.

"The persistent strength of the three Markit/CIPS PMI surveys suggests that we should expect the economy to grow by 0.8% again in the second quarter, taking GDP to a new all-time high."

He said with the Bank of England expecting the economy to slow in the second half of the year, the persistent strength across manufacturing, construction and services raises the likelihood of policymakers deciding for a pre-emptive rise in interest rates later this year.

"Pressure is building for policymakers to ensure that they do not delay the first rate hike too long and end up having to tighten policy more aggressively than would be the case under an earlier series of small rate hikes," he said.

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee, which sets interest rates, is concerned that while employment has increased, much of it has been among the self-employed and wage rises across most sectors remain weak.

Firms reported that the tightening labour market was starting to drive up wages and their own costs, though they were still unable to pass on higher prices to customers.

webTitle: Argos extends eBay tie-up to bring click-and-collect service to 650 stores

fields.bodyText: Argos is extending its tie-up with online marketplace eBay to enable online shoppers to pick up goods at 650 stores as they capitalise on the growing trend towards click-and-collect services. By the end of this year, about 65,000 eBay sellers are expected to offer items for collection at Argos, rising to 80,000 in 2015. Tanya Lawler, the UK vice-president of eBay, said: "Retail has changed and shoppers are in the driving seat like never before. They want to shop any time, anywhere, on any device, and British shoppers love to click and collect." The deal is the latest in an array of new click-and-collect options for shoppers announced over the past few weeks as retailers try to capitalise on the trend in time for the Christmas shopping rush. The idea is seen by some as the potential saviour of the high street as it connects the fast-growing online shopping world with physical stores. Amazon plans to trial online shopping pick-up lockers in two London Underground car parks this month, joining supermarket Asda, established in six tube station car parks last year, as well as Tesco, Waitrose and parcel locker company InPost. Britons' enthusiasm for click-and-collect services has also seen Network Rail set up a joint venture with Travelex founder Lloyd Dorfman to invest £24m in 300 Doddle pick-up-points at stations. With more than half of British shoppers having now picked up online orders from a store or other convenient spots, Amazon has put collection lockers in Co-op and other stores, while retailers including John Lewis are working with Collect+, a scheme that allows shoppers to pick up and return items bought online at more than 5,000 independent retailers. Argos began trials with eBay in 2013, allowing shoppers to collect goods from 50 online sellers at 150 stores, and Argos boss John Walden has suggested that if the tie-up is successful Argos might look at offering similar services to other retailers or brands. David Robinson, chief operating officer of Argos, said: "Fulfilment is the next retail battleground and Argos's unique model is well placed to leverage this." Sarah Butler

webTitle: Household debt serious threat to UK recovery, says Bank of England deputy

fields.bodyText: High household debt is a key risk to the recovery, the Bank of England deputy governor Sir Jon Cunliffe has warned, saying the Bank's measures to rein in the housing market should be thought of as insurance against a major crash. In a speech at the International Festival for Business in Liverpool, Cunliffe said UK household debt was equal to 135% of household earnings, compared with 110% in 2000, although it reached 165% in the runup to the financial crisis. The level was markedly higher than in other European countries and on a par with the US, he said. Last week, the Bank's financial policy committee (FPC) laid out the first limits on the mortgage market in 30 years, to limit risky lending. Lenders must check that mortgage applicants can cope with a rise of three percentage points in interest rates – slightly tougher than current affordability checks – and from October there will be a 15% cap on the number of mortgages that banks and building societies can give to people who want to borrow more than 4.5 times their income. Cunliffe, in charge of financial stability at the central bank, said the main risk from the housing market was that house prices would continue to grow strongly and faster than earnings and lead to more household debt: "In short, the risk that more people take on higher debt relative to their income as they have to stretch further to buy homes." "An outcome in which house prices grow more rapidly relative to income and do so for longer is … quite plausible," he said. "It has certainly happened before in the UK. We know the pressure from demand for homes is great and that the supply of new homes is quite weak. "The stress test of the major UK banks towards the end of the year will assess the resilience of the system to a major crash," he said. "The steps taken last week are insurance against the possibility of a sustained boom in the housing market leading to a substantial increase and concentration in household debt that could make a crash more likely and more severe." His comments came after figures from Nationwide, Britain's biggest building society, showed that the average price of a property in London had risen by more than a quarter, to £400,404, over the past year, a rate of growth not seen since the summer of 1987. In an earlier interview with BBC Radio 5 Live, Cunliffe identified the housing market as the "biggest risk" to the UK economy. A few days ago he warned said that Britain's obsession with home ownership could leave the Bank powerless to control household debt . The International Monetary Fund has told the government that rapidly growing house prices are the biggest threat to the UK's economic recovery.

webTitle: UK services PMI - what the economists say

fields.standfirst: The latest batch of PMI surveys continue to underline the impressive pace of growth in the UK economy
fields.body:
Karen Ward, senior global economist, HSBC

Activity in the UK service sector is still robust and supports our view that growth in the second quarter will be at least as robust as that registered in the first. But this recovery was a long time coming and the level of GDP is still well below that which would have been anticipated pre-crisis.

When viewed in this context of the level of activity rather than growth rates it’s clear there is still a lot of slack to be absorbed. This makes it less surprising that inflationary pressures are not mounting (see chart).

In the service sector more than 50% of total costs are labour costs on average. The fact that this subcomponent remains reasonably subdued suggests wages are not accelerating. Until they do the Bank of England is likely to maintain interest rates at their current rate and focus on cooling excesses in the property market with macroprudential policy.

Howard Archer, chief economist at IHS Global Insight

Recent sustained robust economic activity and elevated confidence in the outlook is supporting demand across a wide range of business services, such as marketing and advertising, public relations, corporate finance transactions, IT provision, accountancy, legal advice, recruitment, training and haulage. Meanwhile, the overall substantial pick up in housing market activity is helping estate agents and a number of other property-related services.

Furthermore, much improved confidence has led consumers to increase their discretionary purchases on consumer services. The Bank of England agents reported in their June summary of business conditions that “consumers were increasingly willing to spend on leisure activities, such as pubs, restaurants and hotels. The travel industry had reported a robust start to the season for both domestic and foreign travel”.

Martin Beck, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club

Today’s release yields a number of positive messages beyond the headline number. Firms appear to be on a mission to increase their recruitment drive, as rising backlogs of work are stretching their ability to meet new orders. And workers appear to be sharing in the bounty of rising activity, through stronger wage growth. Yet competitive pressures are keeping prices in check, helping to lift the purchasing power of households. So overall, the consumer looks set to remain a key driver of the UK economy.

Sam Hill, senior UK economist, RBC Capital Markets

The latest batch of PMI surveys continue to underline the impressive pace of growth in the UK economy. Although the Services PMI fell to 57.7 from 58.6 there were increases in the Manufacturing and Construction indices on the month. The high weighting of Services dragged the Composite PMI down from 59.0 to 58.0 this month but the employment sub-component made a record high at 58.2 up from 55.9 in May.

The other striking aspect of this set of PMI data is the case for ongoing optimism implied by the new orders / new business indices. For all three sectors there was a jump from below 60 to above 60 on those new orders measures pointing to plenty of momentum in the recovery in H2 2014. The PMI-based indicator for GDP is pointing to Q2 GDP growth of 1.1% q/q, although this hasn’t been particularly accurate of late.

Rob Wood, chief UK economist, Berenberg bank

The UK is experiencing a balanced strong expansion that should result in a rate hike in November this year. The PMI’s signal accelerating UK growth in the second quarter. The composite PMI rose to an average of 58.7 in the second quarter from 58.2 in Q1, signalling a pick-up in growth momentum. “There is little sign that growth will slow from this rapid clip with forward looking aspects of the surveys remaining strong. Manufacturing new orders rose in Jun at their fastest pace since November 2013 while services firms’ new business flows jumped by the most in six months. Employment is booming. We expect the UK to grow by 0.9% qoq in Q2 and by above consensus rates of 3.2% and 3.3% in 2014 and 2015 respectively.

Michael Saunders, UK economist, Citi

With gains this month in the PMIs for manufacturing and construction, our composite PMI, a weighted average of the readings for services (50% weight), manufacturing (35%) and construction (15%) edged up to 58.4 in June from 58.2 in May. Both this measure, and the services PMI, remain well above their long-run averages and hence are consistent with continued above-trend economic growth.

The PMI also suggests that job growth will continue to exceed the MPC’s forecasts, with the index of firms’ hiring at a record high. With buoyant economic growth and the sharp drop in the cost of labour (real wages have been falling since 2007 and UK hourly labour costs are now similar to the level in Spain, expressed in a common currency), we expect that strong job growth will cut the jobless rate to about 6% at the end of this year and about 5% at the end of 2015.

webTitle: Thorntons unveils £75m refinancing and discovers breach of borrowing limits

fields.standfirst: Company says it needs to increase borrowing limits to avoid another problem
fields.body:
Thorntons' investors can look forward to tucking into two updates in a week after the chocolate specialist unveiled details of a refinancing ahead of a trading statement.

Its fourth quarter statement is due on 9 July but the company has now said it had seen a positive performance for the year, and full year profits were expected to be in line with City forecasts of £7.1m, up from £4.7m. Its commercial division - selling choc boxes to supermarkets et al - returned to double digit revenue growth in the fourth quarter, it said.

Its existing bank facilities of £57.5m are due to run out in October 2015 but it has agreed an increased figure of £75m until 2018. This will help "support the continuing growth of Thorntons and its transformation into a fast moving consumer goods company with increasing sales to third party retailers."

But Thorntons admitted that the refinancing had revealed that it had inadvertently breached its borrowing limit a number of times over the past few years - because its reserves were reduced under international accounting standards when its pensions deficit was included on the balance sheet. It has called a shareholder meeting to approve raising the borrowing limit, adding:

Without such approval the company is likely to again exceed its current borrowing limit and be in breach of its existing facilities and accordingly would be required to take all possible steps to correct this.

But the refinancing news has helped push Thorntons's shares up 7% to 114.5p. Analyst Peter Smedley at Charles Stanley said:

[The refinancing] underpins our confidence that Thorntons continues to successfully navigate the recovery phase of its transformation strategy and will therefore have the funding commitment over the next four years to enter a more distinctive growth phase. This [update] should also reassure those investors unsettled by the third quarter statement with the confirmation that 1) 2014 pretax profit is anticipated to be in-line with consensus expectations of £7.1m, and 2) as expected, the critical UK Commercial channel returned to double-digit percentage revenue growth in the fourth quarter following an unanticipated decline of 8% in the third after several consecutive quarters of strong growth.
We still believe, therefore, that the transformation strategy remains on track to deliver further significant operational and financial improvements. We retain our buy, reassured by today's statement, but will likely review our current 200p price target with the more detailed fourth quarter trading update due on July 9. [The] increased facility size reflects (1) increased capex to provide extra manufacturing capacity on hollow decorated chocolate models (i.e. Easter eggs) and inlaid boxed chocolates, and 2) the likely significantly increased working capital requirements associated with the company growing its business materially with the UK supermarket channels and other third party retailers over the next few years. As part of the refinancing process, it emerged very recently that the company has previously inadvertently exceeded a borrowing limit set out in the articles of association. A breach of articles may well be taken badly by some investors, but we consider it more of a technicality given the banks' continued support, commitment and actions to agreeing the new financing arrangements. We fully expect that the refinancing will be finalised sometime in August.

Investec also issued a buy note, with analyst Nicola Mallard also unworried by the banking breach:

As part of this debt refinance exercise it has become evident that the group has previously inadvertently exceeded a borrowing limit set out in the Articles of Association, of 2.5 times adjusted capital and reserves. Reserves in recent years have been eroded by increases in international accounting standards deficits for the pension fund. This is a technical breach and in no way connected to bank covenants. It has caused no issues with the lending banks, who are fully supportive and can be readily resolved by increasing this limit in future to a maximum of £100m or 2.5 times reserves.

webTitle: World Cup slowing film sales, says Cineworld

fields.bodyText: Cineworld took a hit as more people preferred to watch the World Cup than go to the cinema in recent weeks. However, with new blockbusters out soon, the largest British cinema operator said it was still on track with its plans for the year. The company, which runs more than 200 cinemas in the UK, Ireland, eastern Europe and Israel, said box office revenues were up 1.5% and admissions rose 1% in the half year to 26 June. The Lego Movie was the highlight of the first half of the year. But in the final weeks "admissions in certain countries have been lower due to the World Cup", which contributed to a decline in box office revenues, Cineworld said. It said that the studios held back big new films to avoid clashing with the World Cup, just as they had done during the Olympics, but the company said a strong film lineup in the coming weeks would offset that in the second half of the year. New releases include the latest from the Transformers franchise, Age of Extinction, and the new Marvel film Guardians of the Galaxy. Cineworld said: "Taking into account the strength of film lineup in the second half, we are on track with our plans for the year as a whole." The company's Picturehouse screens have been the subject of low-pay protests fronted by celebrities including Eric Cantona and Russell Brand in recent weeks. Around 80% of Cineworld staff are employed on zero-hours contracts. Total revenues climbed 33% in the first half, benefiting from the group's acquisition of Cinema City International in January. Customers were also spending more on food and drink after the company installed Starbucks franchises in the UK. Two new cinemas with a total of 12 screens opened in the first half and a further 64 screens are expected to open over the rest of the year.

webTitle: Wage gap opens up between younger and older workers

fields.standfirst: Those who joined the workforce in 1975 have suffered the biggest wage falls during the financial crisis
fields.body:
People who started work in Britain in the 1970s have fared worse in pay terms over their careers than those starting out in the 1990s.

Workers beginning their careers in 1995 were paid an average of 40% more in real terms – when adjusted for inflation – in their first 18 years than those who started in 1975 according to a new report by the Office for National Statistics.

The difference in pay means that people beginning their career in 1975 would have to work up to four years longer than those starting work in 1985 to accumulate the same amount of earnings, and up to six years longer than those starting in 1995.

“On average, individuals who were 21 in 1975 have fared worse in terms of average pay over their career to 2013 than those who were 21 in 1985 and 1995,” the ONS said.

All three groups have suffered a fall in real pay since 2009, as inflation outpaced wage growth, driving living standards lower.

However, those who joined the workforce in 1975 have suffered the biggest wage falls during the financial crisis.

Average pay for workers starting out almost 40 years ago fell by 12% to £11.03 an hour in 2013 from a peak of £12.54 an hour in 2009. The equivalent fall for those who started out 20 years ago was a smaller 10%, to £12.72 last year from £14.12 in 2009.

“Some of the decline for the 1975 group may be explained by people in their late 50s beginning to consider retirement, with the highest earners often retiring early. This would bring down average pay before any consideration is taken of the wider economic conditions.”

The ONS said the pay gap between men and women under the age of 30 had “decreased dramatically” since 1975.

Wage inequality has also fallen since the introduction of the National Minimum Wage in 1999. In 2013 the highest paid employees earned 11 times more than the lowest paid, down from 13 times in 1998.

There are regional variations however, with wage inequality highest in London in 2013, and lowest in Wales.

webTitle: Serco to write down lossmaking contracts further

fields.standfirst: Review of contracts is expected to be completed in time for its annual results
fields.body:
Embattled outsourcing group Serco warned it would have to write down the value of several big contracts relating to asylum seekers' accommodation centres and clinical healthcare, after new boss Rupert Soames embarked on a review of the business. The move could harm annual profits, although for the time being the firm is sticking with previous guidance.

The company has become mired in a series of scandals and recently disclosed that 10 of its staff had been fired in relation to allegations of improper sexual contact with female detainees at the Yarl's Wood immigration detention centre.

Soames said: "Whilst difficulties continue on some contracts, overall our trading and financial position is in line with the expectations on which we updated the market two months ago. We are rebuilding trust and confidence with the UK government and the strategy review is proceeding according to plan."

Serco still expects to make adjusted operating profits of at least £170m at constant currencies, with adjusted revenues flat at £2.4bn in the first half of the year. The company won more than £2bn of contracts during that time.

However, it flagged up likely further writedowns of £10-15m for its Compass asylum seekers' accommodation centres and clinical healthcare contracts, which could affect its stated profit expectations.

Serco's review of its lossmaking contracts such as Compass – which has lost £15m so far and is still losing money – is expected to be completed in time for its annual results. It also had to write down its underperforming UK clinical healthcare contracts by £18m last year.

Serco, often described as the "biggest company you've never heard of", runs a host of government and other services in Britain and around the world, such as rail franchises, prisons and school inspections. It has come under fire for providing "substandard" services over the past year, has seen its stock market value slump and been cast out of the FTSE 100 index.

As private involvement in the NHS grows, Serco has won a number of healthcare contracts, such as running out-of-hours GP services in Cornwall. The service was damned by the House Of Commons public accounts committee which found Serco had replaced clinicians out of hours with call-handlers without medical training.

webTitle: Bwin.party recovers after worries about PokerStars merger

fields.standfirst: Numis says bwin could benefit as deal shows banks are willing to fund online groups
fields.body:
Shares in online gaming group bwin.party digital have been on the slide since a major merger in the sector was unveiled last month.

Canada's Amaya Gaming Group said it would pay $4.9bn for Rational Group, owner and operator of the world's biggest online poker company PokerStars. The deal will be funded by a mixture of cash, new credit facilities and equity.

Worries about the competitive impact of the deal on bwin have undermined its shares, but they have edged up 0.45p to 95.5p after a more positive view of the situation.

Referencing comedy classic Dad's Army in a note entitled Corporal Jones versus Private Fraser, analyst Ivor Jones at Numis - the company's advisor - said:

The significance for bwin.party of the acquisition of PokerStars by Amaya has rather polarised opinions. We take the "don't panic" perspective of Corporal Jones (naturally): a major competitor is about to be loaded with debt, lose its founding management and be more exposed to regulators. Private Fraser however says "we're dooomed": PokerStars will get into the US and, in the rest of the world, with added casino games, mop up all the growth in the market. Time will tell who is right. However, one thing is clear from the deal. Online gaming companies can raise more bank debt than we thought.

On that theme, he added:

Does anyone have the phone number for Deutsche Bank, Barclays or Macquarie? It seems the online gambling sector is more bankable than we thought. One of [activist investor] Spring Owl's proposals was that bwin.party should borrow, return the proceeds to shareholders and operate with net debt. Given the risks surrounding the business we thought it unlikely that banks would provide a material amount of debt. And yet, frankly to our astonishment, the banks named above have contributed to providing $2.9bn of facilities to enable Amaya to purchase PokerStars against projected pro-forma EBITDA for 2014 of "$600-640m" or 4.5-4.8 times EBITDA.
Borrowing on these multiples by bwin.party would imply around €530m-€560m of new debt, or 54%-58% of the current market cap. The interims may bring an update from management on bwin.party's borrowing potential.

webTitle: Serco slips on contract warning, but FTSE moves higher ahead of ECB and US jobs

fields.standfirst: Outsourcer says will take provisions on asylum seekers and healthcare contracts
fields.body:
Rupert Soames is clearly taking the kitchen sink approach to troubled outsourcer Serco.

The grandson of Winston Churchill, who recently moved from Aggreko to become the company's chief executive, has warned that it will need to take some provisions in its first half figures for a number of loss-making contracts.

These include the Compass programme which provides accommodation and support services for asylum seekers, and clinical healthcare contract, in particular in Suffolk. It expects further provisions of £10m to £15m could be required. On top of that half of the £15m costs of its renewal programme and the bulk of the £15m to £20m charges related to restructuring and job cuts would be taken in the first half.

Serco said operating profit for the full year would still be around £170m but warned its strategic review (expected to take nine months) included looking at the carrying value of its assets, and any further financial consequences could impact its expectations for the full year.

The company has already downgraded 2014 profit forecasts three times, launched a share placing to raise cash, and spent time trying to regain the trust of the UK government after overcharging it on contracts to tag criminals. But Soames said:

Whilst difficulties continue on some contracts, overall our trading and financial position is in line with the expectations on which we updated the market two months ago.
There are many challenges ahead, but I am confident that we can build a strong future for the business.

There was no update on a new finance director.

Serco's shares are off 3.3p at 363p but have recovered from the day's low of 357.9p. In a hold note Liberum said:

We expect [the strategic review] to be far reaching, and include consideration of the portfolio of businesses, the appropriate leverage and the dividend policy.
The only certainty is uncertainty until March 2015. Beyond that, we do not see why the business cannot achieve 5% on £4.7bn of sales, or £235m of EBIT. If improved prudence restores faith in earnings and increased focus on return on invested capital improves cash flow, the business may be capable of healing itself and will also attract a much higher rating. But it will be a long slog.

Overall markets are moving higher ahead of the European Central Bank - no change expected - and the US non-farm payroll numbers. The FTSE 100 is currently up 24.02 points at 6840.39.

Sports Direct International is the biggest riser in the leading index after shareholders approved the controversial bonus plan for Mike Ashley (and others, of course). Its shares are up 25.5p at 753.5p. Liberum analysts said:

From an investment perspective, we think that resolution of this issue removes a degree of uncertainty around the business and we can now re-focus on the longer term growth story.
There are still issues that need to be resolved around the relationship with adidas, but a recent visit to the new Oxford St flagship gives a strong indication of Sports Direct's intent to improve its store format gradually. We would see the recent share price weakness as an opportunity to buy ahead of preliminary results on 17 July (we expect the company to meet market expectations of around £330m underlying EBITDA).

Still with retail, Poundland has put 14.5p to 343.2p after well received results showed an 18% rise in first quarter sales.

Tesco is up 4.5p at 289.45p and Morrisons has added 3.1p to 182.7p after Nomura added both to its European recommended portfolio.

But Balfour Beatty has slumped 26.4p or 11% to 206.6p after it said it would take a £35m hit to profits following poor trading at its mechanical and electrical engineering division.

Brewer Greene King has lost 28.5p to 818.5p despite a 7.4% rise in full year profits to £173.1m, as trading in the early part of the year proved disappointing. Numis said:

We are holding our consensus-in- line 2015 forecasts, which anticipate 4% pretax profit growth. Given this and having missed out in the bidding for Orchid, we expect Greene King to be looking for acquisitions.
However, like for like sales are up a disappointing 1.1% in early 2015 despite the fine weather, the World Cup and relatively easy comparisons.

Lower down the market MoPowered has lost 10% to 28.75p after the mobile commerce specialist - which warned on Tuesday that contract delays would hit its results - said finance director Ben Carswell was stepping down with immediate effect.

webTitle: Poundland profits rise amid international growth plans

fields.standfirst: Discount retailer, which floated on the stock market this year, reports 23% rise in pretax profits to £36.8m
fields.body:
Poundland is to launch a website in time for Christmas as the discount chain looks to become a shopping destination for no-frills stocking fillers, confectionery and partyware.

Its chief executive, Jim McCarthy, said the site would focus on successful niches such as paraphernalia for events ranging from children's parties to Halloween and secret santas. He declined to give further details ahead of its autumn launch.

Poundland reported a 23.5% rise in annual profits as it began its expansion into continental Europe with the opening of its first store in Spain on Wednesday.

The firm, one of a raft of retailers to float on the stock market this year, has made a strong start to its new financial year and its maiden results met profit forecasts. Sales climbed 18% to £262.6m in its first quarter to 29 June. The news propelled Poundland shares 4% higher to 342p, up 13.5p and above the float price of 300p.

The Poundland chief executive, Jim McCarthy, said: "We are confident of further progress through the year whilst recognising our critical third quarter lies ahead of us."

He hailed a "transformational year" for Poundland, which listed in March with a stock market value of £750m and runs 528 stores. He said the next leg of its international expansion was under way with the opening of its first Spanish store in Torremolinos under the name Dealz.

This forms part of plans to double the UK's store presence and open 60 new shops this financial year, including a number of Dealz shops in Ireland and Spain. Poundland made an underlying pretax profit of £36.8m in the year to 30 March, up 23.5%, while on a statutory basis pretax profit dropped 18.9% to £21.5m. The latter figure includes IPO costs of £10m.

Poundland serves nearly 5 million customers each week, including more than 200,000 in Ireland. It opened 70 new stores in the past year. Poundland has managed to pull in more shoppers from higher-income groups, with more than 22% of customers now from the AB demographic.

Analysts at ETX Capital said: "There has been an increased tendency for consumers to choose discount retail options, reflected in burgeoning sales for companies such as Lidl and Aldi. Now it seems that Poundland is also reaping the benefits of bargain-based buying trends. The firm sells a large number of products found in supermarkets, particularly beverages and snacks, as well as homeware like lightbulbs – all for much cheaper than the big four UK food retailers."

The company has also paid down debt to £4.7m from £9.2m.

webTitle: BP loses battle to trademark the colour green in Australia

fields.standfirst: Intellectual property watchdog finds no convincing evidence to link the average motorist's mind to the oil giant's dark shade
fields.body:
The oil giant BP has again failed in its long-running bid to trademark the colour green in Australia.

The intellectual property watchdog, IP Australia, found BP was unable to show “convincing evidence” that it was indelibly linked in the average petrol consumer’s mind to the dark green shade known as Pantone 348C, a spokeswoman for the government agency said.

BP first tried to register a trademark for the colour in 1991, and until 2013 fought legal battles against another corporate titan, Woolworths, to stake its claim to the colour as the dominant shade for its service stations.

A spokeswoman for the energy company did not confirm whether BP would continue trying to claim the colour, saying only: “The colour green has been central to the BP brand since the 1930s and we believe it should be protected.”

Colours, like sounds and smells, are particularly hard to trademark, because a company needs to prove the shade sufficiently distinguishes its brand from others.

Some companies have succeeded. The Queensland fruit grower Fada has claimed the red wax that covers the bottom third of its bananas. The American jeweller Tiffany has a trademark in some jurisdictions on its traditional blue hue, while in Australia the pet-food brand Whiskas has won the right to the colour purple.

But even then, says Bruce Arnold, a University of Canberra law professor specialising in IP law, the trademark applies only narrowly.

“People sometimes think that someone is going to actually own a particular colour, but it’s not as simple as that,” he said. “It’s a particular shade of colour that the rights holder owns, which they only use to identify their goods and services.

“So if BP had got green, it could have claimed that shade in relation to their products, but I could still wear a green jumper or a green tie.”

BP’s most recent claim on the colour extended to fuel, car service stations and take-away food services.

Arnold said courts were more likely to grant a colour trademark if doing so would minimise or prevent consumer confusion. He gave the example of Cadbury, which recently won a trademark on the colour purple in the UK, on the grounds that customers angling for a fix of the company’s chocolate were likely to grab for any purple-wrapped confectionery product.

But these confusion claims have been harder to prove in Australia. In 2011 the hardware chain Mitre 10 sought an injunction against a newcomer to the market, Masters, whose white lettering on blue background, Mitre 10 said, would trick consumers into thinking the stores were affiliated, or the same.

The injunction was denied, the judge reasoning that white and blue were standard colours for hardware brands, that Mitre 10 had been using the colours only since 2007, and that, “in the face of clearly different names and marks labelling the rival stores”, no customer was likely to confuse the two.

“When colour trademarks were first introduced in Australia, there was speculation we’d have major problems,” Arnold said. “There was speculation that law firms would be pushing colour trademarks to a range of businesses, and we’d see a wave of trademark registration.

“But that hasn’t happened. Basically, colour trademarks look like a bit of a fizzer,” he said.

webTitle: Mothercare rejects £266m approach from US firm Destination Maternity

fields.bodyText: The boss of a US retailer that has laid out two takeover plans for Mothercare is to fly to London to persuade shareholders to put pressure on its directors to enter talks. The Destination Maternity chief executive, Ed Krell, is to embark on a charm offensive to persuade investors of the merits of a deal and outline the rationale of his £266m takeover proposal. Last night he called on shareholders to press the board into talks. "We really think our latest offer of £3 [per share] is very attractive. We are very hopeful … they will want Mothercare's board to engage with us," he said. Destination Maternity runs 1,906 stores in North America but is smaller than Mothercare in terms of stock market value. It claims to be the world's biggest seller of maternity wear but its attempts to expand outside the US have been limited. It intends to revive Mothercare's 220 UK stores by adding its own products. Krell talked of a "halo effect" – by luring in shoppers earlier in their pregnancy. Destination Maternity's approach at 300p a share, including 230p in cash, was 29% higher than Mothercare's closing price on Tuesday and 90% more than the price on 26 May – the day before the US firm's first approach at 250p-275p a share. Mothercare shares last night closed up 19.5p at 252p, well short of the proposed bid price. The Philadelphia-based company said the combined business would be incorporated in Britain with its shares traded in the US. Mothercare is the third UK business in recent weeks to be targeted by US companies wanting to relocate to the UK for tax reasons while keeping their share listing in the US. The British drug companies AstraZeneca and Shire have both rebuffed approaches from rivals proposing a so-called tax inversion into the UK. Krell denied tax savings were the main reason behind the proposed takeover. "It's the icing on the cake, not the cake itself. The cake is creating a global leader." He added: "We believe there is a compelling strategic rationale for a combination of Destination Maternity and Mothercare, which would create the undisputed global leader in maternity, baby and young children's apparel and products." Mothercare's 1,221 international stores are another attraction. Krell refused to say whether he would mount a hostile bid if he could not persuade the firm to talk takeover terms. "We want to do a transaction that has the support of the Mothercare board and we want to engage with them on a friendly basis. If something really makes sense there should be a way to make that happen." Mothercare has struggled in recent years and in January issued a profits warning. Its dire trading led to the departure of Simon Calver as chief executive in February. But it reported better than expected annual profits in May and revealed that banks to which it owes £46.5m had given its turnaround plan more time. Alan Parker, the Mothercare chairman, said the US company's offer was too low and its proposals did not "reflect the inherent value of Mothercare to our shareholders or its prospects for recovery and growth. In addition, we have significant concerns about the deliverability of these proposals. Mothercare has a very strong and valuable international business and significant potential for sustained improvement in the UK." Sanjay Vidyarthi, an analyst at Liberum Capital, suggested that Destination's "ability to execute the deal is not clear-cut. The rationale for the business combination is also not obvious in terms of solving Mothercare's UK problems." Destination Maternity has also suffered poor trading and issued a profit warning in April, predicting falling annual sales. Its net profit for the three months to the end of March almost halved. fields.headline: Mothercare rejects £266m approach from US firm Destination Maternity
fields.body:
The boss of a US retailer that has laid out two takeover plans for Mothercare is to fly to London to persuade shareholders to put pressure on its directors to enter talks.

The Destination Maternity chief executive, Ed Krell, is to embark on a charm offensive to persuade investors of the merits of a deal and outline the rationale of his £266m takeover proposal.

Last night he called on shareholders to press the board into talks. "We really think our latest offer of £3 [per share] is very attractive. We are very hopeful … they will want Mothercare's board to engage with us," he said.

Destination Maternity runs 1,906 stores in North America but is smaller than Mothercare in terms of stock market value. It claims to be the world's biggest seller of maternity wear but its attempts to expand outside the US have been limited. It intends to revive Mothercare's 220 UK stores by adding its own products. Krell talked of a "halo effect" – by luring in shoppers earlier in their pregnancy.

Destination Maternity's approach at 300p a share, including 230p in cash, was 29% higher than Mothercare's closing price on Tuesday and 90% more than the price on 26 May – the day before the US firm's first approach at 250p-275p a share.

Mothercare shares last night closed up 19.5p at 252p, well short of the proposed bid price.

The Philadelphia-based company said the combined business would be incorporated in Britain with its shares traded in the US. Mothercare is the third UK business in recent weeks to be targeted by US companies wanting to relocate to the UK for tax reasons while keeping their share listing in the US. webTitle: Commonwealth Bank announces review program for financial planning victims

fields.standfirst: Compensation scheme offers no extra redress for customers who suffered the knock-on effects from losing their savings
fields.body:
The Commonwealth Bank has announced a “far-reaching” review program for all customers who accepted advice from any adviser during the time of fraudulent misconduct by some advisers, in the wake of a Senate inquiry into the financial scandal.

However the compensation element of the scheme offers no extra redress for clients who may have lost their life savings up to 11 years ago and suffered the knock-on effects to their cost of living, according to information given by the bank’s chief executive on Thursday.

The head of the Commonwealth Bank Australia (CBA), Ian Narev, “unreservedly" apologised to the customers affected by the actions of financial advisers and other staff at Commonwealth Financial Planning Limited.

A Senate inquiry into the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (Asic) and the Commonwealth Bank scandal last week labelled the conduct of “a number of rogue advisers” unethical, dishonest, a grievous breach of duties and deliberate neglect of clients, in order to benefit their own interests. It also found the CBA’s compliance regime failed, and both the bank and Asic “seemed to place reports of fraud in the ‘too-hard basket’”. It called for a royal commission to investigate.

Some actions included clients with “conservative risk positions” such as retirees having their investments placed in high-risk products without their knowledge by an adviser who would receive bonuses and recognition as a “high performer”.

“We are truly sorry and we acknowledge the financial hardship you suffered as a result of the poor advice, and that is the most critical message underlying what we’re doing today,” said Narev.

The Open Advice Review Program, which Narev said would be operational by mid-August, offers any clients of the bank’s Commonwealth Financial Planning or Financial Wisdom businesses between September 2003 and 1 July 2012 an assessment of any advice they received. Following the assessment, the client will be offered an “independent customer advocate”.

Should the client disagree with CBA’s assessment of their advice they can access a further review by an independent panel to determine compensation. The CBA will be bound by those outcomes but the clients will not be if they wish to pursue it further.

Any compensation will be based on the difference between the actual outcome and what would have happened to the client’s investment if the adviser had not acted fraudulently and had instead placed them in the correct portfolio.

Asked by Guardian Australia if that meant there was no consideration for extra compensation for clients who have dealt with the fallout from their losses for up to 10 years as a result of the advisers’ actions, Narev confirmed this.

“We’re going to be dealing with it on the basis that whatever portfolio they should have been put in compared to the portfolio they were put in, and trace the performance over the time that they’ve owned it,” he said.

“To that extent we’re still sort of on market risk on some aspect of those portfolios because of the time that has lapsed since they’ve held the investments.”

John Berrill, a principal at Maurice Blackburn lawyers, which acted for a number of victims who went through the original CBA review scheme, said there should be compensation for the knock-on effects of fraudulent advice.

“There’s no doubt that, for example, if a retiree bought a house in anticipation that they were going to have a nest egg of a certain amount, and then they have a nest egg that’s a lot less than that because of this financial advice, and they had to sell the house when the market was low –that’s a consequential loss,” Berrill told Guardian Australia.

“Consequential losses is an integral part of damages under the law,” he said.

“It should be included, if it’s not – and that’s consistent with how they have previously operated – then people have to consider their other options, which is basically taking things to court.”

Beyond the cost of offering the assessment and panel services, CBA will not be paying any substantial extra cost than if the advisers had offered the right advice.

“Had the advisers behaved in the appropriate way in the first place it wouldn’t have cost us anything, because people would have been put in the right portfolios,” Narev said.

“Even people in the right portfolios did suffer a loss in the value of their investments in the global financial crisis, so what this scheme doesn’t do is insulate everybody against what a number of people lost during the global financial crisis. It simply says we are on the hook for the difference between the performance of the portfolio you ought to have been put in, versus the one you actually were put in.”

Narev would not disclose the cost of the scheme but said their modelling showed the amount was “not material to shareholders”.

“We are doing this bottom up and doing this customer by customer. Specifically we are not saying there will be a pool of x and divide it up by customers,” he said.

Commonwealth Bank has already paid $52m in compensation to more than 1,100 affected customers through a 2010 remediation scheme, and Narev said because the bank felt it was doing the right thing, an “air of defensiveness came down about the way we were dealing with this whole issue”.

He said that increasing defensiveness has been replaced with a spirit of openness.

“We’ve heard people tell us that the scheme ought to extend to more people than it does today,” he said.

Narev also refused to be drawn on calls for a royal commission into the scandal. “Our view is that … the program we’re announcing today is the right response,” he said.

In his statement he acknowledged “there are some views among some customers, and indeed the Senate report released last week, that our approach has not been sufficient for all our customers. We have listened carefully and this program is a direct response to those concerns.”

webTitle: Why raising interest rates would  hammer the Australian economy

fields.standfirst: The Reserve Bank of Australia is wise to be resisting the international push to lift rates to prevent another financial crisis
fields.body:
On Tuesday, the Reserve Bank as expected kept interest rates steady for another month. The cash rate has now been 2.5% for 12 months. The decision came in the same week the Bank of International Settlements (BIS) – commonly called the central bank of central banks – called for interest rates to be increased to prevent another financial crisis.

Given raising rates would kill Australia’s already fragile economic growth, the RBA is fortunately not heeding the BIS’s advice. The last time the RBA changed rates was in August 2013 when it cut them it them from 2.75% to the 50-year low of 2.5%:

So low is the cash rate that it is more than half the level of the 20-year average. The standard variable mortgage rate as well is at rock bottom levels, and sits around 130 basis points below the average rate of the past 10 years:

And these low rates are set to continue. As this year has gone on, the market has pushed out further and further its expectations of when the RBA will next raise rates. In February the market predicted rates would rise by April 2015; now it is not until late next year:

Part of the reason is found in two pieces of data which came out this week – the RBA’s index of commodity prices, and the balance of payments. The index of commodity prices showed that the price of our exports has fallen 11% since December and they are now back at 2010 levels:

This drop means that even though the amount of iron ore and other metals being shipped off to China and other countries is increasing, the amount of money we are getting for these exports is falling – because the quantity of exports is not rising fast enough to counter the decline in prices.

Thus on Wednesday Australia’s balance of payments (the difference between the amount of money we earned from exports over the amount of money spent on imports) showed a deficit of $679m – down from a surplus of $643m in January.

The RBA anticipated this, noting in its statement on Tuesday that while the most recent GDP figures showed strong growth “this resulted mainly from very strong increases in resource exports as new capacity came on stream; smaller increases in such exports are likely in coming quarters.”

We are seeing those smaller increases now. It suggests GDP growth in the June quarter will have to come from somewhere besides the mining exports.

Indeed the RBA continues to forecast GDP growth “to be a little below trend [around 3.2% to 3.5%] over the year ahead.”

And with lower growth anticipated, there is little chance the RBA will raise interest rates, as that would stifle growth – as borrowing costs for both home owners and businesses would rise.

But this puts the RBA somewhat in conflict with the advice from the BIS which suggested in its latest annual report that central banks should start raising rates.

This isn’t all that new from the BIS. As American economist Paul Krugman has noted, the BIS has been calling for higher interest rates for many years – first to stop inflation, and when that didn’t occur but instead deflation became the concern, it shifted to calling for rate rises because of rising debt levels and because it believes the current record low rates around the world are fuelling easy money and unsafe borrowing by banks.

It argues that failing to raise interest rates now “would exacerbate a country’s vulnerability” to shocks when interest rates are raised later.

As economist Richard Green noted rather pithily on Twitter, the BIS is basically arguing that “the troubling trend of interest rates not rising means that interest rates must be raised lest we face interest rates not rising”.

But although tightening monetary policy slows demand in the economy, the BIS also argues that the fiscal side needs to be tightened as well. It argues that “putting the fiscal house in order is paramount; the temptation to stray from this path should be resisted”.

So the BIS wants central banks to raise interest rates even though this will stifle economic recovery from the GFC because it wants to stop banks lending irresponsibly in a manner that caused the GFC. And it wants governments to tighten their budgets to help stifle that recovery even more.

The RBA, however, is in no rush to take its advice, and one of the main reasons is because our exchange rate remains high despite the fall in export prices.

In normal times the exchange rate rises and falls largely in line with our export prices. After January 2012 this occurred, but from the start of this year the value of our dollar has risen while commodity prices have slumped:

Were the RBA to raise rates, the dollar would rise even further, not only dampening investment in the economy, but making life even harder for exporters and hinder the ability for the non-mining sector of the economy to grow.

The BIS does suggest central banks could use macroprudential tools, which regulate bank lending behaviour, but in the end it argues that raising interest rates is the only way ahead.

Much like a person with only a hammer thinking every problem is a nail, as a conservative austerity favouring central bank, the BIS thinks every problem can be solved with higher interest rates.

Fortunately our central bank seems in no rush to start hammering nails into our economy.
